message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Predefined-Time Fault-Tolerant Consensus Tracking Control for Multi-UAV Systems With Prescribed Performance and Attitude Constraints
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on the predefined-time faulttolerant consensus tracking control problem for multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) systems with prescribed performance and attitude constraints. The UAV systems are divided into the position subsystems and the attitude subsystems for consideration. In the position subsystem, a predefined-time consensus protocol is formulated by modifying the conventional prescribed performance control schemes. The advantage of our work is that the tracking errors can be consistently positive or negative during system operation while achieving the demanded tracking accuracy within the predefined time. In the attitude subsystem, an output-dependent universal barrier function is constructed to realize the attitude output constraints and remove the restrictive assumption that Euler angles should satisfy specific ranges in the existing results. Considering the actuators of UAVs are vulnerable to faults in hostile working environment, an adaptive compensation mechanism is developed to improve the fault tolerance of multi-UAV systems. Finally, the proposed control scheme is applied to power patrol inspection missions to verify its feasibility and effectiveness
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs):

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Key Characteristics

UAVs include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).(no content)A UAV differs from a cruise missile in that a UAV is intended to be recovered after its mission, while a cruise missile impacts its target.

## Historical Development

The earliest attempt at a powered UAV was A. M. Low's "Aerial Target" in 1916, with Geoffrey de Havilland's monoplane being confirmed as the one that flew under control on 21 March 1917 using his radio system.(no content)By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs, with China, Iran, Israel, Pakistan, Turkey, and others designing and building their own varieties.

## Modern Applications

UAVs no longer perform solely intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance missions, although these still remain their predominant tasks. They are also used for combat operations, with military and civilian applications expanding significantly.

Web search results for query: "Euler angles attitude control"

Links: [{"title":"Euler angles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles"},{"title":"Spacecraft attitude determination and control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacecraft_attitude_control"},{"title":"Aircraft flight dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_flight_dynamics"},{"title":"Spacecraft attitude control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attitude_control_(spacecraft)"},{"title":"Davenport chained rotations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davenport_chained_rotations"},{"title":"Orientation (geometry) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_position"},{"title":"Aircraft principal axes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_principal_axes"},{"title":"Conversion between quaternions and Euler angles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversion_between_quaternions_and_Euler_angles"},{"title":"Talk:Conversion between quaternions and Euler angles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Conversion_between_quaternions_and_Euler_angles"},{"title":"Euler's rotation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler's_rotation_theorem"}]

I've completed the web search for "Euler angles attitude control". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Euler angles are three angles introduced by Leonhard Euler to describe the orientation of a rigid body with respect to a fixed coordinate system.

## Use in Attitude Control

Spacecraft attitude control is the process of controlling the orientation of a spacecraft with respect to an inertial frame of reference, and controlling vehicle attitude requires actuators to apply the torques needed to orient the vehicle to a desired attitude, and algorithms to command the actuators.(no content)Error signals are commonly measured as euler angles (, , ), and using a simple proportionalintegralderivative controller (PID controller) satisfies most control needs.

## Advantages and Limitations

While Euler angles offer advantages, they have important limitations: Euler angles are oftentimes the most straightforward representation to visualize, they can cause problems for highly-maneuverable systems because of a phenomenon known as Gimbal lock.(no content)Quaternions offer a decent compromise in that they do not suffer from gimbal lock and only require four values to fully describe the attitude.

## Aerospace Applications

The TaitBryan convention is normally used for aerospace applications, so that zero degrees elevation represents the horizontal attitude, and TaitBryan angles represent the orientation of the aircraft with respect to the world frame.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Fault-tolerant systems control"

Links: [{"title":"Fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Software fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Control reconfiguration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reconfiguration"},{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Fail-safe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fail-safe"},{"title":"Jakob Stoustrup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Stoustrup"},{"title":"Fault detection and isolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_detection_and_isolation"},{"title":"Category:Fault-tolerant computer systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fault-tolerant_computer_systems"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Configurable Fault Tolerant Processor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configurable_Fault_Tolerant_Processor"}]

I've performed a web search for "Fault-tolerant systems control" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here's an overview of what the search revealed:

## Key Concepts

Fault tolerance typically describes computer systems that ensure the overall system remains functional despite hardware or software issues.(no content)Fault-tolerant systems avoid service failure when faults are introduced to the system.(no content)The normal method to tolerate faults is to have several computers continually test the parts of a system, and switch on hot spares for failing subsystems.

## Control Reconfiguration

Control reconfiguration is an active approach in control theory to achieve fault-tolerant control for dynamic systems, used when severe faults such as actuator or sensor outages cause a break-up of the control loop, which must be restructured to prevent failure at the system level.(no content)Prior to control reconfiguration, it must be at least determined whether a fault has occurred (fault detection) and if so, which components are affected (fault isolation).

## Fault Detection and Isolation

Fault detection, isolation, and recovery (FDIR) is a subfield of control engineering which concerns itself with monitoring a system, identifying when a fault has occurred, and pinpointing the type of fault and its location.

## Design Approaches

Several design patterns are used to create fault-tolerant systems, including N-model redundancy, where faults cause automatic fail-safes and a warning to the operator, and it is still the most common form of level one fault-tolerant design in use today.

The search results provide detailed information about fault-tolerant system design, control strategies, and real-world applications in critical systems like nuclear reactors and aircraft.

## Adaptive Control Systems

Here's what I found about adaptive control systems:

### Definition
Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain. For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### How It Works
Adaptive control uses on-line identification of the process parameters, or modification of controller gains, thereby obtaining strong robustness properties.(no content)The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

### Key Difference from Robust Control
Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Historical Background
Adaptive controls were applied for the first time in the aerospace industry in the 1950s, and have found particular success in that field.

### Real-World Applications
Adaptive control systems are used in various applications, including:
- Adaptive flight control
- Adaptive traffic control systems, where traffic signal timing changes, or adapts, based on actual traffic demand
- Adaptive cruise control, a type of advanced driver-assistance system for road vehicles that automatically adjusts the vehicle speed to maintain a safe distance from vehicles ahead

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control"},{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Atomic broadcast - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_broadcast"},{"title":"Quorum (distributed computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quorum_(distributed_computing)"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"State machine replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_machine_replication"},{"title":"Consistency model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistency_model"}]

I've completed a web search for "Consensus control distributed systems." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value needed during computation.

## Applications

Example applications of consensus include agreeing on what transactions to commit to a database in which order, state machine replication, and atomic broadcasts.(no content)Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

## Consensus Dynamics

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agentssuch as robots, sensors, or decision-makersinteracting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## Key Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems. These algorithms are typically synchronous, dependent on an elected leader to make progress, and tolerate only crashes and not Byzantine failures.

## Fundamental Limits

In a fully asynchronous message-passing distributed system in which at least one process may have a crash failure, it has been proven in the famous 1985 FLP impossibility result by Fischer, Lynch and Paterson that a deterministic algorithm for achieving consensus is impossible.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Control track - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_track"},{"title":"Linearquadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linearquadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"}]

Here are the search results for "Control theory tracking":

## Overview of Control Theory and Tracking

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems. The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## Tracking in Control Systems

Tracking is a key objective in control theory. The usual objective of control theory is to control a system, often called the plant, so its output follows a desired control signal, called the reference, which may be a fixed or changing value.(no content)In such systems, the open-loop control is termed feedforward and serves to further improve reference tracking performance.

## Feedback Control and Error Correction

To do this a controller is designed, which monitors the output and compares it with the reference. The difference between actual and desired output, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to the input of the system, to bring the actual output closer to the reference.

## Key Concepts

Controllability is an important property of a control system and plays a crucial role in many regulation problems, such as the stabilization of unstable systems using feedback, tracking problems, obtaining optimal control strategies, or, simply prescribing an input that has a desired effect on the state.

The search results provide comprehensive information about control theory fundamentals and how tracking mechanisms work within control systems.

## Overview of Control Theory and Tracking

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems. The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## Tracking in Control Systems

Tracking is a key objective in control theory. The usual objective of control theory is to control a system, often called the plant, so its output follows a desired control signal, called the reference, which may be a fixed or changing value.(no content)In such systems, the open-loop control is termed feedforward and serves to further improve reference tracking performance.

## Feedback Control and Error Correction

To do this a controller is designed, which monitors the output and compares it with the reference. The difference between actual and desired output, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to the input of the system, to bring the actual output closer to the reference.

## Key Concepts

Controllability is an important property of a control system and plays a crucial role in many regulation problems, such as the stabilization of unstable systems using feedback, tracking problems, obtaining optimal control strategies, or, simply prescribing an input that has a desired effect on the state.

The search results provide comprehensive information about control theory fundamentals and how tracking mechanisms work within control systems.

Here are the search results for "Barrier function control constraints":

## Overview

In constrained optimization, a barrier function is a continuous function whose value increases to infinity as its argument approaches the boundary of the feasible region of an optimization problem.(no content)Such functions are used to replace inequality constraints by a penalizing term in the objective function that is easier to handle.

## Key Characteristics

A barrier function is also called an interior penalty function, as it is a penalty function that forces the solution to remain within the interior of the feasible region.(no content)The two most common types of barrier functions are inverse barrier functions and logarithmic barrier functions.

## Application to Control

In the context of control systems, barrier functions have important applications. A barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system, and can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.

## Interior-Point Methods

A convex optimization program with constraints can be converted to an unconstrained program by adding a barrier function, and practically, it is possible to solve it as an unconstrained program, since any solver trying to minimize the function will not approach the boundary, where the barrier approaches infinity.

These methods are fundamental to modern optimization approaches used in control systems and constrained optimization problems.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multi-agent systems consensus:

## Overview

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agentssuch as robots, sensors, or decision-makersinteracting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## The Consensus Problem

The consensus problem in multi-agent systems has the goal of ensuring that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.(no content)The consensus problem is a fundamental problem in controlling multi-agent systems.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space. Additionally, real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

## Consensus Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems. These algorithms are typically synchronous, dependent on an elected leader to make progress, and tolerate only crashes and not Byzantine failures.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as 'contribution' or 'survey'. Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=['en.wikipedia.org'] to search '[entity name]' to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=['en.wikipedia.org'] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Predefined-Time Fault-Tolerant Consensus Tracking Control for Multi-UAV Systems With Prescribed Performance and Attitude Constraints". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution

The paper proposes novel control methodologies for multi-UAV systems, making it a contribution paper.

**Identified Triples (8 total):**

1. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (uses) - The primary application domain
2. **Consensus dynamics** (proposes) - A predefined-time consensus protocol is proposed
3. **Fault tolerance** (uses) - Core requirement addressed via adaptive mechanisms
4. **Adaptive control** (proposes) - Adaptive compensation mechanism for actuator faults
5. **Barrier function** (proposes) - Output-dependent universal barrier function for attitude constraints
6. **Euler angles** (uses) - Used for attitude representation in the control system
7. **Control theory** (uses) - Foundation for the consensus tracking control scheme
8. **Multi-agent system** (uses) - Framework for coordinating multiple UAVs

**Entity Type Distribution:**
- Tasks: 2 (Unmanned aerial vehicle, Multi-agent system)
- Methods: 3 (Consensus dynamics, Adaptive control, Barrier function)
- Concepts: 3 (Fault tolerance, Euler angles, Control theory)

**Validation Status:**  PASSED

All triples have been validated with correct Wikipedia URLs, proper entity classifications, and clear relevance statements explaining how each technology relates to the paper's contributions.

Sources:
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Consensus dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics)
- [Fault tolerance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Barrier function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_function)
- [Euler angles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
